title: SEC Chairman Scolds Weak Anticorruption Enforcement Abroad
text:
The chairman of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission chided counterparts around the world for spotty enforcement of antibribery laws.

In a speech in New York on Monday, Jay Clayton said countries that neglect to punish corporate bribery create a two-tiered system that gives their domestic companies a leg up on U.S. firms that face punishment for not following the law.

“For the past two plus decades we have vigorously enforced the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act or ‘FCPA,’ ” Mr. Clayton said. “We should, however, recognize that we are acting largely alone and other countries may be incentivized to play, and I believe some are in fact playing, strategies that take advantage of our laudable efforts.”

Of 44 countries that have agreed to make corruption of public officials a crime, 21 have never concluded an enforcement action, according to a December 2018 survey by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Mr. Clayton said he would not unilaterally ease how his agency enforces the law, which forbids U.S. companies and executives from trading favors or paying money to win business overseas.

But the chairman said he would press his concerns with overseas regulators and anticorruption cops.

“Laws, without enforcement, are just words,” he told the audience at the Economic Club of New York.

Mr. Clayton”s remarks echoed criticisms he made as a corporate lawyer in 2011, when he led a New York City Bar Association committee that said the antibribery regime “tends to place disproportionate burdens on U.S. regulated companies in international transactions.”

“Speaking for myself, I have not seen sufficiently meaningful improvement,” he said.

Separately, Mr. Clayton said market regulators are examining the growth of corporate debt and how investors are managing the risk that comes with it.

Corporate debt now stands at $11 trillion, or 50% of gross domestic product, Mr. Clayton said. More than a decade of low interest rates has encouraged companies to issue more debt, while investors looking for better returns have pushed into riskier bank loans and lower-rated bonds that pay higher returns.

“Should we be cognizant of the growth in corporate debt, who holds that debt and the potential ramifications for our markets and our economy?” he said. “Of course we should.”

Mr. Clayton said regulators would have to examine the effects of this leverage as bond prices continue to rise, fueled by concerns of an economic slowdown.

He added that “many economic indicators are very strong” but that regulators must consider how investors will respond if conditions change.

“The upside has become more limited, while the downside has not improved,” he said.

description: Jay Clayton, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, chided counterparts around the world for spotty enforcement of antibribery laws.
